abstract: Molybdenum (Mo) stable isotopes hold great potential to investigate the processes involved in planetary formation and differentiation. However their use is currently hampered by the lack of understanding of the dominant controls driving mass-dependent fractionations at high temperature. Here we investigate the role of magmatic processes and mantle source heterogeneities on the Mo isotope composition of Mid-Ocean Ridges Basalts (MORBs) using samples from two contrasting ridge segments: (1) the extremely fast spreading Pacific–Antarctic (66–41°S) section devoid of plume influence and; (2) the slow spreading Mohns–Knipovich segment (77–71°N) intercepted by the Jan Mayen Plume (71°N). We show that significant variations in Mo stable isotope composition exist in MORBs with δ98/95Mo ranging from −0.24‰ to +0.15‰ (relative to NIST SRM3134). The absence of correlation between δ98/95Mo and indices of magma differentiation or partial melting suggests a negligible impact of these processes on the isotopic variations observed. On the other hand, the δ98/95Mo variations seem to be associated with changes in radiogenic isotope signatures and rare earth element ratios (e.g., (La/Sm)N), suggesting mantle source heterogeneities as a dominant factor for the δ98/95Mo variations amongst MORBs. The heaviest Mo isotope compositions correspond to the most enriched signatures, suggesting that recycled crustal components are isotopically heavy compared to the uncontaminated depleted mantle. The uncontaminated depleted mantle shows slightly sub-chondritic δ98/95Mo, which cannot be produced by core formation and, therefore, more likely result from extensive anterior partial melting of the mantle. Consequently, the primitive δ98/95Mo composition of the depleted mantle appears overprinted by the effects of both partial melting and crustal recycling.

author_highlights.sentence: MORBs present a large range of δ98/95Mo (−0.24 to +0.15‰).
δ98/95Mo variations in MORBs are not produced by magma differentiation.
δ98/95Mo variations in MORBs are not produced by different degrees of partial melting.
Mantle heterogeneity results from anterior magma extraction and crustal recycling.

body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: This is confirmed in Fig. 5b, c which shows that δ98/95Mo does not vary systematically with the degree of differentiation, with the most evolved glass compositions overlapping within error those of the most mafic samples.
body_text.title: Role of magma differentiation

body_text.sentence: Mohns–Knipovich and Jan Mayen samples are basaltic with MgO between 4.8 and 8.7 wt.
body_text.title: Major and trace elements and radiogenic isotopes

body_text.sentence: Molybdenum was separated from the sample matrix by a three stage column chemistry, using cation (BioRad AG50W-X8), anion (AG1X8) and TRU-Spec resin (Burkhardt et al., 2014).
body_text.title: Analytical method

body_text.sentence: Trace element concentrations and radiogenic isotope compositions of the Mohns–Knipovich and Jan Mayen samples show the same range of composition as found by Blichert-Toft et al. (2005) at the same localities.
body_text.title: Major and trace elements and radiogenic isotopes

body_text.sentence: The variable origin and evolution of the mantle endmembers involved in the sample sources would also explain the absence of clear global relationships between δ98/95Mo and other isotopic systems, such as 176Hf/177Hf or 206/207/208Pb/204Pb (see the Supplementary Material).
body_text.title: δMo98/95 and source enrichment

body_text.sentence: Finally, some or all of the δ98/95Mo heterogeneities observed in the current mantle might already have existed during the Archean and, in this case, may be important for the interpretation of the δ98/95Mo signature of Archean komatiites previously used to determine the δ98/95Mo of the BSE (Greber et al., 2015).
body_text.title: Implication for the δMo98/95 of the bulk silicate Earth

body_text.sentence: Other dominant processes occurring at Mid-oceanic Ridges are the interaction of magma with hydrothermally modified crust and with hydrothermal brines during its storage and ascent.
body_text.title: Role of crust and hydrothermal fluid assimilation

body_text.sentence: Major and trace elements as well as various radiogenic and stable isotope compositions were already available for many of the samples selected (as detailed in the previous section) and were obtained for some samples as explained in the Supplementary Material.
body_text.title: Analytical method

body_text.sentence: Fig. 6a–c shows that relationships exist between δ98/95Mo and (La/Sm)N, 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd (Fig. 6a, b, c), suggesting that mantle heterogeneities exert some control on Mo isotope variations.
body_text.title: δMo98/95 and source enrichment

metadata.title: The effects of magmatic processes and crustal recycling on the molybdenum stable isotopic composition of Mid-Ocean Ridge Basalts
